title: Timeliness of OEDA customer services
text:
Starting November 1, 2025 OEDA follows ODHSOHA 010-033 Customer Service and Response Policy
Additional information is available on the OWL page on ODHS Customer Service Policy.

title: Timeliness of OEDA customer services
text:
Summary of the policy

Customers
According to the policy customers include the people we serve, partner, and work with. Specifically mentioned in the policy are coworkers within ODHS and OHA.


Same-or-next business day: Acknowledge the bid for interaction
All interactions–phone call, voice mail, email, instant message, text–should be acknowledged within one-business day. I believe this should also include submissions to request forms.
If the one-day response does is not intended to resolve the customer’s issue, the acknowledgement could be

An auto-reply indicating planned leave, including expected date of return and alternative contacts
A personal response requesting additional information
A personal response providing additional information
A personal response referring the customer to another person, process, or resource
A personal response with a timeline for future responses to resolve the issue



Within 5 business days: Follow up with a plan for resolution
If you will not be resolving the request straight away, within 5 business days of the interaction, share plans with the customer with anticipated timelines for completion of the response.


Within 15 or 30 days: Resolution of the interaction
In the absence of legislation, rule, policy, CBA, or established processes (like procurement), the policy sets expectations that

Most interactions are complete within 15 business days
Almost all interactions are complete within 30 business days



Additional expectations

Provide routine status updated when completion timelines are projected to be longer than 30 days
Provide customers information about current expected timelines, given the amount of work requested, current workloads, and capacity
Provide customers with links to a webpage with standard timelines, and any current systemic issues impacting likely timelines

title: Timeliness of OEDA customer services
section: What does this mean for OEDA?
text:
What does this mean for OEDA?

Our customers are primarily ODHS-OHA coworkers, but we also have interactions with third-parties seeking data or analysis. We should consider our cross-agency partners as customers, as well.
Individuals should plan to meet the 1-day expectations for initial handling of emails
Individuals should use auto-replies when away on planned leave; tailoring them with applicable dates

Suggested message: “I am out of the office [start date] to [end date]. If your request is an urgent one, please contact my manager, Jason Wallin jason.m.wallin@odhsoha.oregon.gov. Helpful links: Schedule a meeting with ORRAI management or the research teams. Request a research project.”

If you employ auto-replies in other ways, we will need to review those
Triaging requests may need a weekly cadence, rather than fortnightly
We need to provide regular updates to customers for lengthy projects
We will need to consider how OEDA or ORRAI will meet the letter or the spirit of the 15- or 30-day completion expectations or be prepared with alternatives for OEDA projects

title: OEDA Logos
text:
OEDA logos are available as .svg files, which Quarto handles natively for HTML files. These are vector graphics files with transparent backgrounds, so they should be able to scale well and be legible in most settings.
You can right click on any of the images below and select save as to save them locally on your machine.

title: OEDA Logos
OEDA Advisory Council Meetings
text:
The OEDA Advisory Council meetings are internal, cross-agency coordination meetings for research, analytics, and evaluation staff. The purpose is to share information, build mutual understanding of topics with cross-agency impacts, and explore opportunities for collaboration.
This meeting is not convened to deliberate toward decisions or to make formal recommendations on policy or administrative matters to any of the participating agencies. Any ideas or insights generated will be shared with appropriate decision-making bodies through established channels with each agency.
These meetings to not seem to meet the definitions of decision, deliberation, or governing body as defined under ORS 192.610.

title: Proposal scoring rubric
text:
Proposals for OEDA projects will be written by the OEDA researchers, generally in collaboration with researchers, data experts, or subject matter experts from partner agencies.
Proposals focus on

the matters that partner agencies face: successes, problems, and opportunities
the future state that agencies would like to see, if those matters are addressed
the research questions that, when answered, can help achieve the future state
the research solutions that, when complete, will provide answers to the research questions

title: Proposal scoring rubric
text:
Proposals for OEDA projects will be written by the OEDA researchers, generally in collaboration with researchers, data experts, or subject matter experts from partner agencies.
Proposals focus on

the matters that partner agencies face: successes, problems, and opportunities
the future state that agencies would like to see, if those matters are addressed
the research questions that, when answered, can help achieve the future state
the research solutions that, when complete, will provide answers to the research questions

title: Proposal scoring rubric
text:
Screening proposals
OEDA staff will screen proposals ensuring that they meet a few must have dimensions required of all OEDA proposals.

Screening item 1: Integrated

Text: The proposal is integrative.
OEDA value: OEDA projects are cross-agency and collaborative






Score


Desc






TRUE


The proposed work integrates data from more than one state agency.




FALSE


The proposed work does not integrate data from more than one state agency.







Screening item 2: Redisclosure

Text: The proposal addresses disclosure to third-parties.
OEDA value: OEDA projects are ethical






Score


Desc






TRUE


The proposal explicitly precludes the redisclosure of agency data to anyone other than the contributing agency and OEDA.




FALSE


The proposal does not contain language precluding redisclosure.







Screening item 3: HumanSubjects

Text: The proposal addresses human subjects protections.
OEDA value: OEDA projects are ethical






Score


Desc






TRUE


The proposal provides reasoning that the project does not meet the federal definition of research, so IRB review is not required.




TRUE


The proposal provides reasoning that the project is research, but does not include human subjects, so IRB review is not required.




TRUE


The proposed work is human subjects research and meets one or more of the requirements for review by the Public Health Institutional Review Board. The proposal indicates that chartered work will need review from that body.




TRUE


The proposed work is human subjects research, does not meet any of the requirements for review by the PH-IRB, but includes an attestation from someone other than the investigators that the research is exempt from IRB review.




TRUE


The proposed work is human subjects research and is not exempt. The proposal indicates that chartered work will need review from an IRB.




FALSE


None of the above are true; the proposed work does not adequately address human subjects protections.

title: Proposal scoring rubric
text:
Scoring proposals
Members of the OEDA Advisory Council will score proposals on criteria that relate to the relevance, impact, and urgency of the proposed work.

Scored item 1: Importance

Text: The current state is important to address.
OEDA value: OEDA projects are relevant and impactful






Score


Desc






1


The issue is relevant to a small work unit within a single agency and affects tens of clients.




2


The issue is relevant to several employees across one or two agencies and affects hundreds of clients.




3


The issue is relevant to employees across several agencies, relates to a state priority, and affects several hundreds of clients.




4


The issue is widespread across multiple agencies, relates to one or more key state priorities, and affects thousands of clients.




5


The issue is foundational and cross-agency, with substantial relationships to effective service delivery, and affects tens of thousands of clients.







Scored item 2: Urgency

Text: The current state is urgent to address.
OEDA value: OEDA projects are relevant and impactful






Score


Desc






1


There is no immediate need to address this issue. It can be revisited at a later date with little to no consequence.




2


The issue should be addressed within the next two years, but there are no immediate deadlines or critical events tied to it.




3


The issue needs to be addressed within the year to avoid a negative impact on services or a key initiative.




4


The issue needs to be addressed soon to support an upcoming policy change, a legislative mandate, or a critical program launch.




5


The issue requires immediate attention to avoid a substantial negative outcome, such as a service disruption, public harm, or failure to meet a legal deadline.







Scored item 3: Impact

Text: The future state is an improvement to agency operations and client services.
OEDA value: OEDA projects are relevant and impactful






Score


Desc






1


The proposed future state offers minimal improvements over the status quo, with little potential to change how agencies operate or serve clients.




2


The future state would represent localized, loosely described improvements within one or two state agencies.




3


The future state would be a clear, measureable improvement in specific processes or services across multiple agencies.




4


The future state would be a significant change in how agencies coordinate or make decisions, a new level of efficiency, service quality, or service equity.




5


The future state is a new paradigm for data-informed decision making across multiple agencies, fundamentally changing how government operates and serves its citizens.







Scored item 4: Questions

Text: The research questions are meaningful and useful.
OEDA value: OEDA projects are relevant and impactful






Score


Desc






1


The research topics or questions are vague, unrelated to the core problems or opportunities of the current state, or would not meaningfully contribute to achieving the desired future state.




2


The research topics or questions are too broad, too narrow, or would only provide a partial answer. Significant uncertainty would remain.




3


The questions are clear and directly address the gap between current and future states. Answering the questions would provide the necessary insight to move from the current to future state with reasonable confidence.




4


The questions are insightful and precise, pinpointing the critical information needed to make informed decisions. Answering the questions is likely not to just fill the gap, but reveal new opportunities.




5


The questions are incisive, originally, and essential for project success. Answering these questions would eliminate major uncertainties and provide a high degree of confidence that the desired future state can be achieved.







Scored item 5: Equity

Text: The proposal future state is an improvement to agency operations and client services.
OEDA value: OEDA projects are ethical






Score


Desc






1


The proposal does not adequately acknowledge or consider ethical or equity implications; or there are reasons to believe the work will cause harm or perpetuate existing biases.




2


The proposal mentions ethics or equity, but superficially, promising to meet minimum compliance standards, but without specific details or reasoning, and disconnected from the core project.




3


The proposal includes specific plans related to ethics and equity, like data disaggregation, or including thoughts from those with lived experiences. But improving service equity is not a primary focus of the work.




4


The proposal demonstrates a thoughtful understanding of the ethical and equity landscape–clearly identifying regions, communities, populations relevant to the research questions and providing strong rationale for their inclusion. A project aim is improving service equity, fairness, and equality of outcomes.




5


The proposal includes meaningful engagement with clients in different parts of the state, with a variety of lived experiences, and part of different racial, ethnic, cultural, linguistic, and other communities. Specific metrics for measuring equity are incorporated into the proposed work, and improving those measures is key to the work.

title: Proposal scoring rubric
text:
Details

IRB

The proposal provides reasoning that the project does not meet the federal definition of research, so IRB review is not required

Research means a systematic investigation, including research development, testing, and evaluation, designed to develop or contribute to generalizable knowledge [45 CFR 46.102(l)]

Many common state agency analytics projects involve development and evaluation, but are nonetheless not research. This is generally because they are not designed to develop or contribute to generalizable knowledge. That is, they are not seeking findings that can be applied to populations or situations beyond those studied.
Typical systematic uses of data that are not research include:

Internal program evaluation and quality improvement efforts
Operational activities
Informational interviews



The proposal provides reasoning that the project is research, but does not include human subjects, so IRB review is not required

Human subject means a living individual about whom an investigator (whether professional or student) conducting research: (i) Obtains information or biospecimens through intervention or interaction with the individual, and uses, studies, or analyzes the information or biospecimens (ii) Obtains, uses, studies, analyzes, or generates identifiable private information on identifiable biospecimens 45 CFR 46.102(e)

Often, work with administrative data is neither the result of intervention nor interaction.

Intervention includes both physical procedures by which information or biospecimens are gathered (e.g., venipuncture) and manipulations of the subject or the subject’s environment that are performed for research purposes. 45 CFR 46.102(e)(2)

Generally, researchers for state agencies are not able to create randomized control trials where Oregonians’ experiences with their government are manipulated to develop strong internal validity for generalizable claims.

Interaction includes communication or interpersonal contact between investigator and subject 45 CFR 46.102(e)(3)

Researchers for state agencies are often working with private information.

Private information includes information about behavior that occurs in a context in which an individual can reasonably expect that no observation or recording is taking place, and information that has been provided for specific purposes by an individual and that the individual can reasonably expect will not be made public (e.g., a medical record).

But, researchers can often answer meaningful agency questions without using identifiable private inforamtion.

Identifiable private information is private information for which the identity of the subject is or may readily be ascertained by the investigator or associated with the information.

Analyses using deidentified data, which cannot be reasonably reidentified by the investigator, are generally not considered human subjects, as individual humans can no long be connected to the attributes being studied.
Creating analytical datasets which follow Safe Harbor Regulations is one way to ensure that the analysis does not involve human subjects.


The proposal meets one or more of the requirements for review by the and has received approval from that body
Any study that meets any of the criteria below must seek review by the Public Health Institutional Review Board.

• The research is sponsored by the PHD (Oregon Public Health Division) or MCHD (Multnomah County Health Department);  • The research is conducted by or under the direction of an employee or agent of PHD or MCHD in connection with his/her agency responsibilities, or using any property or facility of PHD or MCHD;  • The research involves the use of PHD or MCHD’s data;  • The research involves the use of PHD or MCHD’s non-public information to identify or contact human research subjects or prospective subjects;  • Funding for the research will be handled through PHD or MCHD, but the research will be done at another location  Public Health Institutional Review Board (p. 3)



The project is human subjects research, but provides a checklist or attestation from someone other than the investigators that the research is exempt from IRB review
While the Federal HHS does not require it, they strong recommend that determinations of exempt status be conducted by individuals other than the investigators.
For context, the PH and MCHD Institutional Review Board requires expedited review by the Board to determine whether a protocol is exempt.
Exempt research includes (among other exemptions):

Research in educational settings involving normal educational practices 45 CFR 46.104(d)(1)
Research whose interactions are only educational tests or observation of public behavior 45 CFR 46.104(d)(2)
Research whose interventions are benign behavioral interventions 45 CFR 46.104(d)(3)
Secondary research for which consent is not required 45 CFR 46.104(d)(4), including specifically the following


The research involves only information collection and analysis involving the investigator’s use of identifiable health information when that use is regulated under 45 CFR parts 160 and 164, subparts A and E, for the purposes of “health care operations” or “research” as those terms are defined at 45 CFR 164.501 or for “public health activities and purposes” as described under 45 CFR 164.512(b);

Where the definitions for health care operations and research defined in 45 CFR 164.501 are

Health care operations means any of the following activities of the covered entity to the extent that the activities are related to covered functions: (1) Conducting quality assessment and improvement activities, including outcomes evaluation and development of clinical guidelines, provided that the obtaining of generalizable knowledge is not the primary purpose of any studies resulting from such activities; patient safety activities (as defined in 42 CFR 3.20); population-based activities relating to improving health or reducing health care costs, protocol development, case management and care coordination, contacting of health care providers and patients with information about treatment alternatives; and related functions that do not include treatment; […] (4) Conducting or arranging for medical review, legal services, and auditing functions, including fraud and abuse detection and compliance programs; (5) Business planning and development, such as conducting cost-management and planning-related analyses related to managing and operating the entity, including formulary development and administration, development or improvement of methods of payment or coverage policies; and (6) Business management and general administrative activities of the entity, including, but not limited to: (i) Management activities relating to implementation of and compliance with the requirements of this subchapter; (ii) Customer service, including the provision of data analyses for policy holders, plan sponsors, or other customers, provided that protected health information is not disclosed to such policy holder, plan sponsor, or customer. […]   Researchmeans a systematic investigation, including research development, testing, and evaluation, designed to develop or contribute to generalizable knowledge.

title: Using the request form
text:
Useful research often starts with a spark–an observation, a question, a comment in a meeting, or a pattern in some data. These sparks can come from anywhere: stakeholders ,audits, internal conversations, or your own insights. But, if they say in our heads or scatterd across notebooks or OneNote pages, we risk losing them.
To make sure we don’t miss valuable opportunities, any time that you hear, see, or think of something that could become a research question, project idea, or line of inquiry, please drop it into the request form.
Don’t worry about polish. Rough ideas are welcome and encouraged.

title: Using the request form
text:
Intentions

Lighten the mental load - no need to remember every idea; we can just drop it in and move on
Get credit for insights - contributions help shape research agendas and demonstrate thought leadership from program staff, OEDA staff, and others
Build momentum - even vague or early-stage ideas can become important projects when they are shared and inspire others
Stay aligned - a shared backlog should help us prioritize, avoid duplication, and be more aware of the changing landscape and emerging needs

title: Using the request form
text:
What happens after submission
We’ll triage submissions regularly–currently fortnightly on Tuesday mornings. In these sessions, we introduce the submissions, open the floor for clarifying questions or early comments, and then we might assign ideas to staff for further development, consultation with subject matter experts, etc.

title: Publishing to GitHub pages
text:
Happy Git and GitHub for the useR
Quarto guidance on publishing to GitHub pages using the docs folder

title: Publishing to GitHub pages
text:
Happy Git and GitHub for the useR
Quarto guidance on publishing to GitHub pages using the docs folder

title: Publishing to GitHub pages
section: Create a git repository if one does not already exist
text:
Create a git repository if one does not already exist

Login to: https://github.com/login
In the left sidebar, click New to create a new repository
Under owner, select ODHS-ORRAI
Set yourself as owner, and give your repository a name, e.g. this website is OEDA-lab-manual
Set the visibility of the repository to Public (hosting websites from Private repositories requires an upgraded GitHub account for ORRAI)
Click Create repository
Click <>Code in the top ribbon
Copy the location from the Quick Setup section. For the OEDA Lab Guide (the website you’re reading), this is https://github.com/wallinjm/OEDA-lab-manual.git

title: Publishing to GitHub pages
section: Create a new R project associated with your new repository
text:
Create a new R project associated with your new repository

Start RStudio
Click File > New Project
Click Version Control
Click Git
In the Repository URL field, paste the URL copied from above
Select the appropriate path location for the project, and name a new folder to hold the project

title: Publishing to GitHub pages
text:
Create the /docs/ subfolder
Within the new folder that RStudio should have just created, make a new /docs/ subfolder.

title: Publishing to GitHub pages
text:
Create your website files
Your _quarto.yml and *.qmd files should be saved in your main project folder, not to /docs/.
When these files are rendered the *.html files will be stored in /docs/.

_quarto.yml
This should look something like the following. The key thing for publishing to GitHub pages in this way is the specification of output-dir: docs in the project: section.

project:
  type: website
  output-dir: docs
  
website:
  title: "Site title"
  navbar:
    left:
      - text: "Page 1 title"
        href: page1.qmd
      - text: "Page 2 title"
        href: page2.qmd


Content pages
Create one or more .qmd files with your content. These generally start with:
---
title: "Page 1 title"
---

Your markdown here.
  


Create a .nojekyll file
Open a Windows Prompt in the Terminal in RStudio to create a .nojekyll file in the root of your git repository. This prevents Github from processing the website in undesirable ways.
You’ll do this just once before you publish your site for the first time.

copy NUL .nojekyll

title: Publishing to GitHub pages
text:
Render your files to docs
First, render your quarto documents.

In the RStudio console run quarto::quarto_render()

Then, create a new Git Back terminal.

Find the Terminal tab in RStudio
Click on the Terminal dropdown
Click Terminal Options
In New terminals open with: select GitBash
Click OK
Click on the Terminal dropdown again
Click New Terminal

In the terminal, type the following

git add docs
git commit -m "Commit note"
git push
Replace “Commit note” with the note that you want to include with this commit. Make sure to use the quote marks.

title: Publishing to GitHub pages
text:
Check in on the commit
If you navigate to your new repository on GitHub– https://github.com/ODHS-ORRAI/your-repository-name-here–you should see a new folder docs in the repository, along with your commit message.

title: Publishing to GitHub pages
section: Configure the repository to use the /docs/ folder
text:
Configure the repository to use the /docs/ folder
From the GitHub.com page for your new repository

Click Settings in the top navigation ribbon
Click Pages in the left side bar
Under Source make sure that Deploy from a branch is selected (it should be the default)
Under Branch there is a dropdown box, select main
A folder dropdown should appear next to the main branch dropdown now. Click it and select /docs.
Click Save

title: Publishing to GitHub pages
section: Check the availability of the new site
text:
Check the availability of the new site
Your new site should (maybe after a short delay) be available at a URL like the URL for this site:
https://odhs-orrai.github.io/OEDA-lab-manual/
You’d replace the last bit with the name of your repository.

title: Publishing to GitHub pages
text:
Make your updates as needed
Whenever you need to make changes or updates to your website, just follow the routine of the last couple of steps detailed above:

Edit your _quarto.yml and *.qmd files as necessary
Save the files locally
In the RStudio console run quarto::quarto_render()
Run the following in your terminal


git add docs
git commit -m "Commit note"
git push
That should be it. After maybe a little network lag, and perhaps forcing a refresh to escape your browser cache, you should see the changes to the live website.

title: Quality checks: Research reports
text:
Quarto uses embed-resources: true in the yaml heading so that the document is a single file with no external dependencies
Quarto compiles without errors and warnings
All outputs render: no broken figures, tables
All citations and bibliography entries appear without breaking, are formatted correctly, and links function as expected
All internal links and references (e.g. Table X, Figure Y, Section Z) work and point to the right content

title: Quality checks: Research reports
text:
Quarto uses embed-resources: true in the yaml heading so that the document is a single file with no external dependencies
Quarto compiles without errors and warnings
All outputs render: no broken figures, tables
All citations and bibliography entries appear without breaking, are formatted correctly, and links function as expected
All internal links and references (e.g. Table X, Figure Y, Section Z) work and point to the right content

title: Quality checks: Research reports
text:
Statistical and analytical integrity

All text has been run through the statcheck package, to determine if reported p-values, df, and test statistics align. Any errors or decision errors have been resolved.
All tests have effect sizes reported.
Confidence intervals are included around point estimates.
Data visualizations and text/data/statistics match (e.g. means in the text match the means in the visualization)

title: Quality checks: Research reports
text:
Reproducibility

Quarto project structure follows OEDA standards (TBD: e.g., report.qmd, figures/, data/, scripts/) for transparency.
Document makes use of a reproducible environment (TBD: determine the OEDA standard: Docker, renv.lock, etc.?)
Seeds are set for simulations, resampling, bootstrapping, or other random processes
Scripts and data used in the document are versioned and reproducible
Code chunks use #| eval: true unless intentionally disabled with a comment as to why
Input data is described or linked clearly (e.g. source, format, preprocessing). Data are all versioned instances, not SQL pulls from “live” administrative data.

title: Quality checks: Research reports
text:
Interpretibility and clarity

Title reflects key findings, variables, populations, and time periods
Abstract reflects key findings, variables, populations, and time periods
Key findings are clearly stated in plain language
The main message is consistent across the title, abstract, results, visualizations, and conclusion
Effects are described in units meaningful to the audience (counts of individuals, dollars, days in care, etc.)
Acronyms and technical terms are minimal, and are defined at first use
Assumptions and limitations are acknowledged as appropriate in introduction, methods, and conclusions, and are addressed in suggestions for future work
Figures and tables are interpretable without reference to the text

title: Quality checks: Research reports
text:
Writing quality style

No placeholder text (ADD, TODO, etc.) remains
Grammar, spelling, and punctuation are correct
Voice and tense are consistent
Readability scores have been calculated and are within OEDA adopted thresholds
Terminology and variable names are consistent throughout

title: Quality checks: Research reports
text:
Ethical, legal, and confidentiality checks

No confidential or identifying information is used in any data input
No confidential or identifying information appears in any output (text, visualization, table, etc.)
Appropriate masking is used for all static elements
Appropriate masking has been tested for with any dynamic elements
All data use complies with licenses, access conditions, and consent
Ethics approval, DUA, IAA, etc. are acknowledged if applicable

title: System 4 Intelligence
text:
OEDA’s System 4 are the activities that help bring our attention outside our immediate context and our day-to-day work. System 4 brings us knowledge of the external environment and potential futures. These help improve the viability of OEDA, by helping us course correct our work for changing environments and to plan for the future.
The ORRAI director is an important source of System 4 intelligence for ODHS and the OEDA Advisory Council is an important source of intelligence for partner agencies. But, the economist and researchers within OEDA can also bring intelligence to the team, if they are given occasional time outside of the day-to-day work to encounter new findings, innovative ideas, and different perspectives.

title: System 4 Intelligence
text:
OEDA’s System 4 are the activities that help bring our attention outside our immediate context and our day-to-day work. System 4 brings us knowledge of the external environment and potential futures. These help improve the viability of OEDA, by helping us course correct our work for changing environments and to plan for the future.
The ORRAI director is an important source of System 4 intelligence for ODHS and the OEDA Advisory Council is an important source of intelligence for partner agencies. But, the economist and researchers within OEDA can also bring intelligence to the team, if they are given occasional time outside of the day-to-day work to encounter new findings, innovative ideas, and different perspectives.

title: System 4 Intelligence
text:
Internal Oregon government documents

Program/agency Ways & Means presentations
Legislative testimony
Program/agency documents: strategic plans, reorg documents, OWL pages, etc.
Secretary of State Audits

title: System 4 Intelligence
text:
Think tanks & policy research
Sources for research reports, briefs, data visualizations, etc. – often with cross-agency topics.

Urban Institute - housing, poverty, TANF, SNAP, justice
Center on Budget and Policy Priorities - federal & state budgets, funding streams and policies, SNAP, TANF, Medicaid
MDRC - evaluations (often randomized controlled trials) of social program - employment, education, family supports
Child Trends - children & youth, child welfare, juvenile justice
Mathematica - research & evaluation solutions - health, human services, education
Chapin Hall - child welfare, youth homelessness, community-based supports
Casey Family Programs - child welfare

title: System 4 Intelligence
text:
Clearinghouses
These organizations review and rate the evidence for specific programs and practices. These can provide standards of evidence, and can also be a source of ideas worth testing or implementing in Oregon.

What Works Clearinghouse - education, including early childhood
Title IV-E Prevention Services Clearinghouse - Child welfare; evaluations and ratings of services eligible for federal prevention funding
CrimeSolutions.gov - Criminal and juvenile justice
California Evidence-Based Clearinghouse for Child Welfare - Child welfare.

title: System 4 Intelligence
text:
Government & membership orgs
Places to learn federal priorities, what other states are doing, and find new data releases.

ACF Office of Planning, Research, and Evaluation (OPRE) - research arm of the Administration for Children & Families, TANF, child welfare, early childhood
USDA Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) - SNAP and other nutrition programs
American Public Human Services Association (APHSA) - membership org for state and local agencies., challenges and innovations happening in other states and jurisdictions
National Conference of State Legislatures (NCSL) - tracking legislative trends in human services across the US
National Data Archive on Child Abuse and Neglect (NDACAN) - child welfare, AFCARS and NCANDS federal files

title: System 4 Intelligence
text:
Foundations
Foundations often fund innovative research and pilot projects years before they become mainstream government practice. Could be a good source for intelligence on what’s on the horizon.

Casey Family Programs - child welfare, juvenile justice, family economic stability Kids Count data center
Robert Wood Johnson Foundation - health and health care, Medicaid, public health, social determinants of health
Pew Charitable Trusts - health & well-being, communities, economic advancement, federal policy, state government, environment, immigration, demography, race, ethnicity, religion, Pew Research Center
Marguerite Casey Foundation - grant making foundation to shift power from government to communities, families, and individuals who continue to be excluded from shaping society and sharing in its rewards and freedoms.

title: System 4 Intelligence
text:
Journals

The Future of Children - defunct collab between Princeton and Brookings, each issue is a highy readable deep-dive into a single topic: education, early childhood, culture & economic outcomes, universal health, reducing justice system inequality, etc.
Journal of Policy Analysis and Management (JPAM) - program evaluation & policy analysis
Social Service Review - social problems, policy, social work practice
Big Data & Society - large-scale data collection, algorithmic decision making, impacts on society, ethics & equity of administrative data
Gateways: International Journal of Community Research and Engagement - empirical & evaluative case studies of community-based research & pedagogy, research with communities rather than on them
Journal of the Royal Statistical Society: Series A (Statistics in Society) - social and ethical implications of statistical methods, algorithmic fairness, data privacy, measuring inequality
Journal of Public Administration Research and Theory (JPART) - public administration, representative bureaucracy, administrative burden, implementation of policy by “street-level” bureaucrats
Public Administration Review (PAR) - public sector research, theory, and practice, academics & practitioners)
Journal of Urban Affairs - housing, transportation, economic development, human services, spatial dimensions of inequality, disparate outcomes
Child Abuse & Neglect
Child Maltreatment
Developmental Child Welfare
Social Science and Medicine
Journal of Family Violence
Journal of Marriage and Family
Children and Youth Review Services

title: OEDA - Lab Manual
text:
This is an early draft of the OEDA Lab Manual. This manual establishes our standard operating procedures, best practices, and resources for conducting OEDA research. It aims to
In Beer’s Viable Systems Model, OEDA staff work alone and in teams as autonomous System 1 units, conducting studies and projects, producing research projects. The OEDA Lab Manual will be an important System 2 support, helping OEDA’s research analysts and economist work without undue intervention, with standards, guidelines, expectations, and resources.

title: OEDA - Lab Manual
text:
OEDA’s Vision (Draft - Proposed August 2025)
Oregon state agencies integrating data to measure performance, test ideas, experiment with options, and improve operations.

title: OEDA - Lab Manual
text:
OEDA’s Mission (Draft - Proposed August 2025)
OEDA provides timely, objective, and independent research and analytics, enabling Oregon’s human services agencies to make informed, effective, and equitable decisions for the well-being of Oregonians.

title: OEDA - Lab Manual
text:
OEDA’s Product Values (Adopted Summer 2025)

Relevant and impactful
Accessible, understandable, & approachable
Rigorous & trustworthy
Innovative

title: OEDA - Lab Manual
text:
OEDA’s Process Values (Adopted Summer 2025)

Ethical
Collaborative
Constructive
Communicative
Managed expectations
Plays well with others
Professional & conscientious

title: OEDA Team Meetings
text: Every Tuesday from 1:35 to 2:55

title: OEDA Team Meetings
text: Every Tuesday from 1:35 to 2:55

title: OEDA Team Meetings
text:
Purposes

Align

Debrief council meetings
Synthesize and analyze intelligence from OEDA staff, agency partners, and other informants
Share project progress and blockers
Review metrics and discuss implicated processes

Plan

Design projects
Set OEDA development calendar

Produce

Agendas and agendas for council meetings
Progress reports for council members and sponsors
Minutes from council meetings

Ideate

Feedback on proposals, research plans, charters, products, presentations

Connection

Get to know one another better
Celebrate individual and team successes

title: OEDA Team Meetings
text:
Agendas

Standing agenda
This is our general, standing agenda for our weekly meetings.

Hot topics: Anything that anyone on the team needs to address at the top of the meeting
Special topics, if scheduled
System 4 Briefings - Briefings from any guests invited for intelligence - Briefings rotating staff on their intelligence areas - Briefings from Jason - Ad hoc briefings from anyone
Systems 1 & 2 Briefings - Updates from work units on project progress - Identification of any blockers or process issues
System 3 Briefings - Lab manual updates - Housekeeping from HR, Workday, admins, etc. - Review of any dashboards, metrics, Kanban, etc. we’re experimenting with



Special topics

Periodic special topics
Schedule is TBD, but we will have a set of period meetings that will occasionally occupy our OEDA Team Meeting time. These will include sessions to debrief from a recent council meeting, sessions to plan for coming council meetings, sessions to create monthly progress reports for the council, etc.
On these dates, we will reserve the last 30 minutes for (at least) scheduled System 4 briefings, any blockers that need management or System 2 supports, and any System 3 urgent or housekeeping updates from Jason.



Ad hoc events
Also during our weekly sessions, we will occasionally schedule time requested by anyone on the team or by guests to engage the team: align on complex info that needs discussion and clarifying questions, make decisions, create products, or get to know one another better and build connection and rapport.

title: Color Palettes
text:
Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.4.3
As our “good enough for now” set of colors, we will adopt the new ODHS color palette as our primary palette for most OEDA publications. The palette is detailed in Brand Guidelines (pp. 41-47; p. 54), available from Publications and Creative Services.

title: Color Palettes
text:
List of basic palette colors
The list below contains the main colors identified in the guidelines.

OEDA_colors <- list(
  northstar = '#2E3192',
  glacial = '#B4DCF5',
  fog = '#F4F2ED',
  forest = '#184E49',
  willamette = '#86C679',
  mist = '#D8E1E5',
  marionberry = '#A91F50',
  harvest = '#ECD263',
  desert = '#EDDFD4',
  black = '#000000',
  white = '#FFFFFF',
  charcoal = '#414042'
)

Vis callouts include the fill color of columns, bars, boxplots, points, etc.

title: Color Palettes
Color Palettes
text:
Other vis palettes
We will make recommendations for other palettes when comparisons are not between a small number of categories, but are multinomous categorical or continuous (sequential or divergent).
